replies.author: @TommyStGeorge
replies.text: There's a huge misrepresentation in the press about what's going on here.  No one left BR, no one seceded from BR, nor carved out a section of BR.  This was an unincorporated area of East Baton Rouge Parish (county) that decided to incorporate into its own city.  East BR Parish has a unique form of government.  It's a consolidated City-Parish government.  The Mayor of BR is also the Parish President.  The City-Parish was taking tax revenue from the unincorporated area, and using it to fund services that were only accessible to citizens that lived within the city limits of BR.  Mostly the BR Fire Department and BR City Police Department, and their retirement funds.  Those departments do not service the unincorporated area that became St. George.  We just got tired of paying for things that we did not have access to.

replies.author: @dtchouros
replies.text: There was a similar situation in Memphis. There were two governments; a city of Memphis and a Shelby county. The city of Memphis was notorious for mishandling their school money. They spent more money per student than anyone in the state of TN but had the lowest scores. When they could no longer get more money, they chose to surrender their charter to the county to consolidate the Memphis and the suburbs (Shelby County) schools to go after that money in basically a hostile takeover. The suburbs asked to make their own school systems for their small cities. After a lot of back and forth, it had to be taken to the state courts where the suburbs won the right to create their own individual systems. So the Memphis schools turned into ‚Äúshelby county schools‚Äù  and the former county schools turned into five individual city school systems. These smaller school systems have continued to be some of the best in the state. The suburbs just wanted to maintain their level of education for their children. If they had allowed Memphis to take them over, their schools would have plummeted to the level of the city schools where a large amount of graduates can barely read. Had they surrendered their charter AND their administration (because they obviously sucked) this may have not happened. They just wanted to take over the suburbs and use their money as well.
